facts.text: Respondent Ramniklal Kothari carried on business in diverse lines as a partner in four different firms.

facts.text: Respondent received income from the different registered firms as his share of profits.

anchor.surface_text: He received from time to time income from the different registered firms as his share of profits. For the assessment year 1955-56 the respondent declared

facts.text: For assessment year 1955-56, respondent declared share of profits from four firms at Rs. 77,027.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1955-56 the respondent declared his share of profits from the four firms at Rs. 77,027/- and he claimed an allowance of Rs. 13,283/-

facts.text: For AY 1955-56, respondent claimed allowance of Rs. 13,283 being payment of salary and bonus to staff, expenses for maintenance and depreciation of motor-car, travelling expenses and interest.

anchor.surface_text: and he claimed an allowance of Rs. 13,283/- being payment of salary and bonus to staff, expenses for maintenance and depreciation of motor-car, travelling expenses and interest.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Hazaribagh allowed the claim for interest and disallowed the rest for AY 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Hazaribagh, allowed the claim for interest as a permissible deduction and disallowed the rest.

facts.text: ITO viewed that respondent did not carry on any independent business, so amounts except interest not claimable on his own account.

facts.text: For AY 1956-57, respondent claimed Rs. 19,380 as admissible deduction including Rs. 1,956 as interest paid.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed an aggregate amount of Rs. 19,380 as admissible deduction on various grounds including Rs. 1,956 as interest paid by him.

facts.text: For AY 1956-57, ITO allowed interest claim and disallowed the rest.

issues.text: Whether the expenses incurred by the assessee who was number carrying on any independent business of his own, in earning income from various firms in which he was a partner, are allowable in law as deductions?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the expenses incurred by the assessee  who was number carrying on any independent business of his own , in earning income from various firms in which he was a partner, are allowable in law as deductions ?

issues.text: Whether the share of profits of a partnership received by a partner constitutes business income liable to tax under S. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 allowing deductions under S. 10(2)?

anchor.surface_text: taxed under S. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Share in the profits of a partnership received by a partner is profits and gains of business carried on by him and is on that account liable to be companyputed under s. 10, and it is a matter of numbermoment that the total profits of the partnership were companyputed in the manner provided by s. 1 0 of the Income-tax Act and allowances admissible to the partnership in the companyputation of the profits and gains were taken into account.

arguments.claim: Since the respondent did not carry on any independent business, the amounts except interest were not claimable by the respondent on his own account; if at all, the amounts should have been claimed as business expenses incurred in the accounts of the four firms.

arguments.court_reasoning: Share of profits is business income under s.10; deductions under s.10(2) allowable even without independent business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the expenses incurred by the assessee  who was number carrying on any independent business of his own , in earning income from various firms in which he was a partner, are allowable in law as deductions ?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: which he was a partner, are allowable in law as deductions ? The High Court of Patna answered the reference in favour of the respondent. With special

arguments.court_reasoning: Affirmed by statutory interpretation and precedents.

holdings.text: Share in the profits of a partnership received by a partner is profits and gains of business carried on by him and is on that account liable to be computed under s. 10, and it is a matter of no moment that the total profits of the partnership were computed in the manner provided by s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and allowances admissible to the partnership in the computation of the profits and gains were taken into account.

anchor.surface_text: taxed under S. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Share in the profits of a partnership received by a partner is profits and gains of business carried on by him and is on that account liable to be computed under s. 10, and it is a matter of no moment that the total

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.10 to partner's share as individual business income, irrespective of firm's computation; harmonious construction with s.23(5)(a)(ii) and s.16(1)(b).

holdings.text: The receipt by the partner is business income for the purpose of s.10(1), and being business income, expenditure necessary for the purpose of earning that income and appropriate allowances are deductible therefrom in determining the taxable income of the partner.

anchor.surface_text: under S. 10 1 . Being income from business, allowances appropriate under S. 10 2  are admissible before the taxable income is determined. Section 23 5  a  ii  provides

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since share is business income under s.10(1), s.10(2) deductions apply; no implication from s.23(5)(a)(ii) or s.16(1)(b) precludes partner-level deductions for earning expenses.

holdings.text: Counsel for the Commissioner accepted, and in our judgment counsel was right in so doing, that the share of the respondent from the profits of the firm was income from business carried on by the partner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession by petitioner counsel confirmed by court as correct application of law.

holdings.text: Business carried on by a firm is business carried on by the partners. Profits of the firm are profits earned by all the partners in carrying on the business.

anchor.surface_text: was income from business carried on by the partner. Business carried on by a firm is business carried on by the partners. Profits of the firm are profits earned by all the partners

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical extension of partnership principles under income-tax law.

holdings.text: The legal principles which we have endeavoured to set out are well settled by several decisions.

anchor.surface_text: In the individual assessment of the partner, his share from the firms business is liable to be taken into account under S. 10 1 . ... The legal principles which we have endeavoured to set out are well settled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference to established precedents confirming allowability of deductions.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with the view expressed by the learned Chief Justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes and rejects Calcutta HC view in Iswardas as not fully argued and based on concession; affirms contrary precedents.
